items.title: Interop 2026 launched: 15 new cross-browser features coming
items.summary: ğŸš€ Frontend Focus #â€‹729 â€” February 18, 2026 | Read on the web Announcing Interop 2026 â€” The Interop project forms the basis for Google, Apple, Igalia, Microsoft, and Mozilla to collaborate each year on implementing the web technology that developers most want and need. This year sees fifteen brand new topics, including improvements to attr() , container style queries, contrast-color() , scroll-driven animations, and tightening up the CSS Scroll Snap spec. Wu and Simmons (WebKit) ğŸ’¡ Each of the partners has announced Interop 2026 and explained their role in it separately, here's Google's post by Rachel Andrew , Jack Archibald writing for Mozilla , Microsoft's take , and Igalia's roundup. We felt WebKit's post (above) just led the way, though, as it includes more code examples! :-) Free Workshop: Debug React Apps With AI From Dev to Prod â€” Seer is Sentry's AI debugging agent. It root causes errors, suggests fixes, and catches bugs before they ship. This free 4-part workshop goes hands-on with each feature. No fluff, just walkthroughs you can follow along with. Sentry sponsor Modern CSS Code Snippets â€” It has a few rough edges, but the core idea of showing a variety of CSS snippets with a before/after showing the â€œoldâ€ way to do something versus the â€œnewâ€ way is neat. I picked up a few quick techniques I wasnâ€™t aware of. Naeem Noor âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF ğŸ¥³ Chrome 145 has been released with support for column-wrap and column-height properties â€“ demos and explanations here. The DevTools have also seen some enhancements. ğŸ•¹ï¸ Not content to merely port Quake to run in the browser , the creator of Three.js now has a Descent port too ( source ). âœ‹ The EU wants to tackle 'addictive UI' patterns like infinite scrolling. ğŸ¤– Google shows off a preview of WebMCP , a proposed standard for sites to offer up abilities to AI agents. ğŸ¤– Cloudflare is rolling out a feature to allow agents to fetch Markdown directly from Cloudflare-powered sites. ğŸ“„ The CSSWG has published a first public working draft of Selectors Level 5. ğŸ“™ Articles, Opinions & Tutorials Implementing Virtual Scrolling at Billion-Row Scale â€” A technical walkthrough of handling DOM limits, scrollbar precision problems, and accessibility constraints in building a table component ( HighTable ) that handles billions of rows efficiently. Sylvain Lesage What Happens When a Web Team Goes All-In on Claude Code â€” Expo's developers share honest lessons from a month of AI-assisted coding: wins, limits, and real productivity gains. Expo sponsor Approximating contrast-color() with Other CSS Features â€” With contrast-color() not yet widely supported, this article derives a one-line CSS formula using oklch() relative color syntax to automatically choose black or white text against any background. Kevin Hamer (CSS Tricks) Gwtar: A Static, Efficient, Single-File HTML Format â€” A technical explanation of a new polyglot HTML archival format that provides a single, self-contained, HTML file but which can be efficiently lazy-loaded by a web browser through the use of some cute techniques. Gwern Justifying text-wrap: pretty â€” â€œAlthough Safari is the first browser to ship a non-joke implementation of text-wrap , the combination with text-align looks ugly..â€ Alex Kladov Building an Endless Procedural Snake with Three.js and WebGL Sujen Phea Making a Responsive Pyramidal Grid with Modern CSS Temani Afif Trying to Make the Perfect Pie Chart in CSS Juan Diego RodrÃ­guez ğŸ§° Tools, Code & Resources Oat: Ultra-Light, No-Dependency HTML UI Component Library â€” This one got a lot of love on social media this week! Oat is built on the idea of just throwing a CSS and JS file into your project (totalling about 8KB gzipped) and getting a complete UI component library at your disposal with a shadcn-inspired aesthetic and without any arduous build steps. Kailash Nadh Clerk's New Pricing: 50,000 MRUs Free on Every Plan â€” First major update since 2023. MFA included in Pro at $20/mo, unlimited apps, and automatic volume discounts as you scale. Clerk sponsor ğŸ•’ Slowmo: Slow Down, Pause, or Speed Up Browser Time â€” Not quite a DeLorean, but a tool (usable in your own code or as an extension) that slows down time in the browser for debugging animations, studying demos, and so on. It slows down a variety of things like CSS animations, transitions, and requestAnimationFrame . Francois Laberge âœ‰ï¸ Maizzle: Build HTML Emails with Tailwind CSS â€” A framework that helps you quickly build HTML emails with Tailwind CSS and a toolchain to apply advanced email optimizations and customizations (like inlining CSS, rendering Markdown, and creating plain text versions). Maizzle TanStack Hotkeys: A Type-Safe, Cross-Platform Hotkey Library â€” An alpha release of a universal keyboard interaction toolkit that tackles all the rough edges and gotchas of different environments. Focused on React for now, but agnostic at its core. TanStack LLC fetch-network-simulator: Intercept fetch to Simulate Poor Network Conditions â€” At its heart is a library that intercepts fetch and applies rules to do things like drop random requests, delay them, or slow them down, so you can see how resilient your app is. Karn Pratap Singh Vercel Introduces 'Geist Pixel' â€” Vercel commissioned a variety of fonts for its Geist design system, with the latest addition being an aliased/bitmap variant . Vercel Ipx.

Frontend Masters sponsor How a ğŸ’” Broken Heart Made a Page 100x Slower in Safari â€” A single emoji brought a dashboard to its knees, dragging out load times to ten seconds. Finding it took a journey through red herrings, performance timelines, and a binary search. The sort of oddity any of us could run into. Allen Pike Interop 2025: A Year of Convergence â€” Work on the Interop project, an initiative that brings together Apple, Google, Microsoft, Mozilla and others to identify the areas of the web platform where interoperability matters most to developers, has concluded its fourth year. Here's an overview of the 2025 efforts, including key features that saw convergence across browsers: Anchor Positioning, View Transitions, and the Navigation API. Nicole Sullivan (WebKit) âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF ğŸ” A quick explainer to WCAG 3.0 , the next generation of the W3C's accessibility standards. It's all work in progress, with a draft candidate recommendation not expected till 2027. âœ¨ If you need some design inspiration, this site brings together a collection of nice HTML UI components that are 'ready to drop into your next project' . âœ… Version 28 of developer browser Polypane is now available , introducing a new Environments feature, improved Elements panel, and more. ğŸ¤” How do browsers work? A high-level overview of how browsers work in practice. ğŸ“™ Articles, Opinions & Tutorials Shades of Halftone â€” A thorough technical tour of all things pixelation, dithering and halftone. Maxime digs into the mathematical implementation of using GLSL shaders to create such effects. I really dig the aesthetic (an increasingly popular one in modern web design generally) explored here. Maxime Heckel The React Native Guide Web Developers Actually Need â€” Built by the Expo team. Learn what works, what breaks, and which libraries everyone actually uses in production. Expo sponsor The Browser Hates Surprises â€” There are techniques you can use to avoid page-loading jank and content from shifting around, even if repainting is still necessary. This post looks at some solutions. Durgesh Rajubhai Pawar â–¶ Whatâ€™s Missing from the Web Platform? â€” A 50~ minute big-picture episode where Scott and Wes run through their wishlist for the web platform (better form controls, various CSS ideas, etc). Syntax podcast A Guide to Browser DevTools - The Network Monitor â€” Provides a solid starting point for getting to grips with the Network Monitor in your workflow â€” a tool that allows us to see and inspect the requests a browser makes as a page loads. Michael Li A Polyfill for the HTML Switch Element â€” Thomas shares a new polyfill designed to bring the native HTML switch element functionality to all modern browsers. Thomas Steiner How (& Why) to Stop Users from Selecting Text on Your Website â€” You can stop text selection with the user-select CSS property . I didnâ€™t know it was something that was in the spec, removed, and then added back again. Rachel Kaufman How an Accessibility Designer Adds Keyboard Shortcuts to a Web App Eric Bailey A New Meta Tag for Respecting Text Scaling on Mobile Manuel Matuzovic Illustrated Guide to Multi-Threaded Rendering on the Web Ashish Shubham Measuring SVG Rendering Time with Node.js Stoyan Stefanov ğŸ§° Tools, Code & Resources The Logo Soup Problem: And How to Solve It â€” Many sites show company logos as social proof, but sizing and laying out logos responsively can be tricky. Luckily, you can now use React Logo Soup instead â€“ hereâ€™s a demo. If React isn't your thing, they also explain the algorithm behind it. Rostislav Melkumyan Peek: A JavaScript Library for 'Smart Header' Behavior â€” You can see it in action on the page. Itâ€™s â€œsmartâ€ in that it will differentiate between small insignificant scrolls and intentional ones. You can customize the thresholds and delays and it works with any framework. Repo here . Chad Pierce Live Data for Dashboards. No Second Database â€” Tiger Data runs analytics on live Postgres data. No pipelines, no sync lag. Extend Postgres instead. Try free . Tiger Data sponsor Invoker Buttons Polyfill: A Polyfill for the Newly Supported command and commandfor HTML Attributes â€” Both features are now baseline newly available since December 2025, but if you want deeper support this script will help. Thereâ€™s a writeup here . Keith Cirkel Shaka Player 5.0: Library for Playing Adaptive Media â€” Plays formats like DASH and HLS in the browser sans plugins. It can also store and play media when offline using IndexedDB. ( Demos. ) Shaka Project broz: A Simple, Frameless Browser for Screenshots â€” Potentially useful if, like me, you're sick of fidgeting around to get a clean screenshot of a site. Anthony Fu SVG Studio: A Browser-Based Tool for Working with SVGs â€” Has quite a few features including optimization, debugging and fixing SVG rendering issues, cleaning up SVGs exported from design tools, and better understanding the underlying code. gavin atkinson ğŸ“¦ ..and finally Toon Text: A Web Tool to Generate Cartoon-Style Text â€” Not for every project, but a unique tool that combines some fun fonts you can choose from with CSS effects. Includes a number of different ways to customize the look before copying the final code. Andy Clarke Ipx.

items.title: Stop rushing to single-column layouts
items.summary: ğŸš€ Frontend Focus #â€‹727 â€” February 4, 2026 | Read on the web The Too Early Breakpoint â€” Ahmad thinks we're collapsing to single-column layouts way too soon. With CSS Grid and Container Queries, we can create smarter breakpoints, fluid transitions, and intermediate views that actually use the space we've got. Ahmad Shadeed SurveyJS: JSON-Driven Form Builder for React, Angular, and Vue â€” Stop hardcoding forms. SurveyJS lets you design complex forms and surveys in JSON using a drag-and-drop UI, connect to any backend, and fully customize behavior and UI. Scalable and ideal for data-heavy applications. Start with a free demo . SurveyJS sponsor Solving 'Shrinkwrap': A New Experimental Technique â€” Roman tackles a CSS problem "deemed impossible" . That is, shrinkwrapping an element with auto-wrapped content. His solution combines anchor positioning and scroll-driven animations, and he posits it could work as a future native feature. A superb explainer with plenty of interactive examples. Roman Komarov No-Hassle Visual Studio Code Theming: Building an Extension â€” One of our most linked frontend authors over the years tackled the task of making his own VS Code theme using modern tooling and shares his insights. He prototyped the palette with Shiki, then wrapped the theme in a minimal extension to preview changes live while tuning scopes. Zell Liew âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF ğŸ—“ï¸ Rachel Andrew rounds up web platform updates from the past month , including Anchor Positioning and the Navigation API reaching Baseline status. ğŸª Popular content site framework Astro 5.17 is now available , introducing partitioned cookies, new image optimization upgrades, and more. ğŸ“‹ Short-lived (six-day) and IP address certificates are now generally available from Letâ€™s Encrypt. ğŸ§­ Here are the release notes for Safari Technology Preview 236 â€” it adds math function support to the sizes attribute of img elements. âœ¨ FranÃ§ois Beaufort shares what's new in WebGPU in Chrome 145. ğŸ“™ Articles, Opinions & Tutorials Drawing Connections with CSS Anchor Positioning â€” A good tutorial that explains the power that anchor positioning unlocks. Roland notes it â€œ feels like layout-aware CSS â€ and is â€œ especially powerful for UI patterns where relationships matter more than strict placement â€. Thereâ€™s a CodePen demo here to illustrate whatâ€™s possible. Roland Franke Performance-Optimized Video Embeds with Zero JavaScript â€” â€œ What if I told you, you could lazy-load videos on interaction, without any JavaScript, even above the fold, with only native HTML and CSS? â€ Stefan Bauer Clerk Skills: AI Agents That Know Current Auth Patterns â€” Run npx skills add clerk/skills to teach Cursor, Copilot, or Claude Code current Clerk patterns for sign-in flows and B2B auth. Clerk sponsor Throttling Individual Network Requests in Chrome DevTools â€” Hereâ€™s a look at a new developer tool (in Chrome 145+) to throttle or block specific network requests. This granular control (found in the Request conditions tab) will help improve debugging/testing, particularly sluggishly loading dependencies. Gasperowicz & Pfaffe (Chrome Developers) Introduction to the New geolocation > Element â€” Support is limited to Chrome for now , but Manuel takes us on a quick tour of this promising new HTML element. Manuel Matuzovic Nice Select â€” Some fun experimentation here pushing the customizable select element to its extremes. Watch the attached video to get an idea of whatâ€™s possible â€“ support is limited right now , but it's really good food for thought! Adam Argyle How the Same Content Always Has Multiple Different Versions â€” An interesting accessibility point here looking at the differences the same content can often have. The visuals here really help make the point. Diana Khalipina Combobox vs. Multiselect vs. Listbox: How To Choose â€” Looks at how each is different, what purpose they serve, and choosing the right one. Vitaly Friedman Building a Scroll-Revealed WebGL Gallery with GSAP, Three.js, Astro and Barba.js â€” A striking visual image reveal effect you can see in this demo. Chakib Mazouni How AI Is Redefining the Way We Find Content Alex Edwards Building a Simple RSS Aggregator with Astro Raymond Camden Bringing CSS Clipping to React Native Kamil Paradowski ğŸ§° Tools, Code & Resources Sweetfont: Find Fonts By 'Vibe' â€” A fun, browser-based tool to surface options available on Google Fonts (from the over 1900 choices available nowadays) based on various characteristics, such as â€˜playfulâ€™, â€˜loudâ€™, â€˜ornateâ€™, â€˜heavyâ€™, etc. Dial in what you want. Peter Cooper Real-Time Analytics Without the Backend Complexity â€” TimescaleDB runs analytics on live operational data without a second database. No pipelines, no lag, no drift. Try free . Tiger Data sponsor EaseMaster: A Tool for Visualizing and Generating Code for Easing Animations â€” Includes a Cubic Bezier Editor and a Spring Physics Engine and has support for exporting CSS transitions, Tailwind, Framer Motion, and GSAP. Repo . Satish Kumar minimal-pwa: A Minimal Set of Files & Config for a Progressive Web App â€” A minimal bare-bones starting point for creating a PWA, with a manifest.json and service worker code to trigger the install on supported browsers. Chris McCormick WarGames Terminal Fonts: A Font Made from the Text Terminal Displays in WarGames â€” A retro typeface based on terminal sessions in the popular 1980s movie. The author created this after noticing â€œsufficient information present on-screenâ€ in the movieâ€™s text terminal displays. Michael Walden ğŸ“¦ ..and finally Flexboxle: A Daily Flexbox Puzzle â€” Here's a fun Wordle-style puzzle where you're challenged to enter the correct CSS Flexbox property values in order to reach the goal output. A good way to practice (or teach) Flexbox concepts and better understand the mental model at play. Flexboxle Ipx.

items.title: When will 'Grid Lanes' truly arrive, and how can we use it today?
items.summary: ğŸš€ Frontend Focus #â€‹726 â€” January 28, 2026 | Read on the web When Will CSS Grid Lanes Arrive? How Long Until We Can Use It? â€” As we shared earlier this month , CSS Grid Lanes is arriving soon across browsers (with Safari already shipping support in Technology Preview). Hereâ€™s a look at the current implementation status and three approaches for progressively enhancing your layouts to use Grid Lanes today while still supporting older browsers. Jen Simmons (WebKit) Add GitHub, Slack & Google Integrations Without Rebuilding OAuth â€” WorkOS Pipes handles OAuth flows, token refresh, and credential storage across multiple providers. Users connect via a widget, and your app makes one API call to get a valid token. Itâ€™s a faster way to ship third-party integrations. WorkOS sponsor Understanding the Fundamentals of CSS Layout â€” A solid guide to demystifying some foundational CSS concepts (flow, box model, positioning, etc), all in an effort to help aid our overall understanding of the language. Thereâ€™s a video version too if youâ€™d prefer. Kilian Valkhof Try Text Scaling Support in Chrome Canary â€” The new text-scale meta tag is now available for testing behind a flag in Canary. Itâ€™s designed to respect a userâ€™s text size preferences on the web, and essentially handle scaling in a way that simply zooming often fails at. Josh sums it up: â€œ the tells the browser, â€˜Hey, Iâ€™ve designed my website to still work if the user increases their OS text sizeâ€™ â€. Josh Tumath âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF ğŸ” Google has announced a restructuring its Programmable Search Engine (PSE) offerings , providing more specialized tools for site exploration, enterprise AI search, and full web indexing. ğŸ–¼ï¸ Support for the JPEG-XL image format has been on something of a journey , but its fortunes are seemingly turning around , slowly. ğŸ¤ Mozilla is attempting to build what it calls an AI 'rebel alliance'. Not everyone is a fan of the plans... ğŸŒ You may think of Netscape as a relic of the 90s, but it had a surprisingly protracted demise â€” the brand was kicking around in until late 2025! ğŸ“™ Articles, Opinions & Tutorials CSS in 2026: New Features Reshaping Frontend Development â€” A laundry list of some of the latest features either now available or on the way, along with how we can go about implementing them in our codebase. Jemima Abu How to Favicon in 2026: Three Files That Fit Most Needs â€” Asks us to â€œ stop the icon generator madness â€ and take a smarter approach, adopting a minimal set of icons that fits most modern needs.
